[6.1s - 12.0s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability podcast series.

[12.7s - 16.3s]: Today we have the opportunity to visit with Stone Hunter.

[29.4s - 35.1s]: And before we start on our tour, let me just tell you a little about Stone's background.

[45.0s - 45.2s]: It is.

[45.7s - 45.8s]: Yeah.

[46.6s - 58.2s]: He's born and raised at Sunrise Ranch and attended the River Song Waldorf School and later graduated from the International Baccalaureate Program in Fort Collins, Colorado.

[58.2s - 71.5s]: After attending Evergreen State College and working on permaculture based projects in Costa Rica and Panama, he began farming in 2013 at Happy Heart Farm in Fort Collins.

[72.3s - 87.9s]: In 2015, Stone began working at Sustainable Settings where he completed a two year North American biodynamic apprenticeship program training with experience in dairy cattle operations, holistic grazing grain cultivation.

[87.9s - 97.3s]: Draft horse implementation, Stone masonry, CSA gardening, green construction, natural beekeeping and more.

[98.2s - 105.9s]: Stone facilitated the project management of the Urias Permaculture Action Days in 2015, 2016 and 2017.

[106.5s - 115.0s]: Currently, he lives in Peonia, Colorado and is working with Skyhawk Construction, Building Straw Bale, Passive Solar Homes,

[115.0s - 120.4s]: while teaching and participating within the permaculture and biodynamic movements.

[121.0s - 133.4s]: And Stone, it's so great to have this opportunity to visit with you and get a sense of what goes into a heart-centric process of building a super high-performing sustainable building.

[133.4s - 134.1s]: So welcome.

[134.4s - 134.7s]: Thank you.

[135.6s - 142.4s]: Yeah, exciting to share a little bit about what we're doing in this small little town of Peonia in the mountains of Colorado.

[152.6s - 156.0s]: And this house we're standing in front of is the Straw Bale home.

[230.1s - 250.2s]: You know, it's so important I know that some of my friends and colleagues at the US Green Building Council have published all kinds of materials and studies indicating a variety of health and respiratory problems tied directly to the sort of mainstream building materials we've been using over the last several decades.

[250.2s - 266.4s]: Many of the finishes, many of the actual framing materials, the carpets, etc, are off-gassing all kinds of carcinogenic chemicals basically, and we know this is one of the contributors to high rates in childhood asthma.

[267.1s - 280.1s]: So to have instead natural materials, which of course is what our species is used to going back in time, obviously is going to have a tremendous health benefits on the

[280.1s - 294.3s]: physical level, and then it sounds like you're also doing beautiful things with the design aesthetic and the energetics of the space to affect us also on the emotional, the mental, the spiritual, the psychological levels.

[294.5s - 301.4s]: Absolutely, yes, so we're paying attention to the materials that we use and where they're sourced from.

[357.3s - 367.2s]: And we were mixing those up on site using sand, local sand, clay, water, and then mixing in some lime for that outside.

[662.4s - 669.7s]: That life kind of moves from the south and we know if we go south towards the equator, the abundance of life that is present there.
